answers.answer: you need more testing.  a new current eye exam and possibly a visit to a neurologist.

question: For the last 3 years I've experienced a dimming (almost blindness) of my vision in my right eye - it only happens when I turn my bedside lamp off & when I'm laying on my left side (it doesn't happen when the light goes out & I'm laying on my right side).My vision is fine laying on that side until the light goes out.  When the light goes out, I can hold my hand an inch in front of my face & can't see it out of my right eye, but can with the left (I see shadows & the hallway light, but the right takes about 3 to 4 minutes for my vision to return to normal).  It started happening maybe 1 to 2 times a month & now happens 3 to 4 times a week.  I've had my carotid artery checked & it is fine.  I have gotten ocular migraines & the past. My blood work is all normal - no diabetes or high blood.My rx is strong -6.00 both eyes.  I saw an opthomologist 2 years ago & he says the optic nerve & everything look fine.  I wonder if a growth in the brain might be putting pressure on something, because this phenomenon only happens laying down on the left side.Could this be a symptom of MS?  I've not been diagnose with MS, but over the years have had occasional symptoms - tingling, numbness, feelings of electrical shocks in legs, eye pain & feelings of eye fullness.Anyway, is there anyone out there that may be experiencing anything like this - if so what is going on with you?  Thanks for listening.
title: Vision Dims When Light Goes Off
